The Far East.JapaneseDeclaration ofWar on GreatBritain and theUnited States ofAmerica.(previous reference erence:W.M. (41) 124thConclusions,Minute 4.)1. The Prime Minister said, that, after he had heard on theprevious night of the Japanese air attacks on Hawaii and singapore, and of the attempted landing at Kota Bahru, he hadrung up President Roosevelt. The latter had said that he would go to Congress on the following day with a message declaring theopening of hostilities. He had replied that we would declare warimmediately after the United States. Later, however, a message had been received from Tokyo that Japan had declared war againstthe United States and Great Britain. (This declaration had beenmade by the Japanese High Command, and not by the JapaneseGovernment.) He had accordingly authorised the Home Secretaryto put our Security arrangements into force, and arrangements hadbeen made for both Houses of Parliament to meet at 3 p.m. that afternoon. , /The Prime Minister hoped that the War Cabinet would authorise him to include in his speech in Parliament that afternoona statement that we had declared war on Japan.The War Cabinet-Agreed that immediate steps should be taken to declare war on Japan, and authorised the immediate despatch ofthe necessary communication to the Japanese Charged'Affaires. (The letter was signed and despatched fromthe Cabinet Room.)The Prime Minister said that for some time past he hadbelieved that, if Japan went to war with the United States, it wouldbe as part of an arrangement whereby Germany and Italy would atthe same time declare war on the United States. This was a development which must be expected in the near future.The Prime Minister said that on the previous night he had sent a message to General Chiang Kai-shek in the following terms : '' British Empire and United States have been attacked by japan. Always we have been friends; now we face a commonenemy."The Prime Minister read to the War Cabinet a draft of the speech he proposed to make that afternoon, and agreed to make ashort broadcast at 9 p.m. that night.The War Cabinet took note, with approval, of the above.Ireland.Prime Minister'message toMr. de Valera.(previous reference:W;M. The Prime Minister said that on the previous night, afterconsultation with the Dominions Secretary, he had sent a personal telegram to Mr. de Valera to say that now was Eire's chance tocome into the war on our side, and offering to meet Mr. de Valeraat any time. :Later in the Meeting a telegram was received from our HighCommissioner in Dublin reporting (a) that Mr. de Valera, to whom the message had been delivered, was somewhat apprehensive lest a meeting with the Prime Minister at this time might provokeaction from extremists;(6) that Mr. de Valera proposed to discuss the matter with his cabinet that day.The War Cabinet took note of this statement.Naval, Militaryand air operations.(previous reference:W.M. The Chiefs of Staff gave the following information in amplification of Cabinet War Room Records Nos. 821-827 :-Summary of aircraft losses since the 1st December : Home Theatre Our'Own- 7 fighters.3 bombers.7 Coastal Command Aircraft.Enemy 7 destroyed.1 probable. '33 destroyed.5 damaged. : ' .In Home Waters eight enemy merchant vessels had been hit and two probably hit.Malaya. Eighteen Japanese aircraft had attacked Singapore the' previous evening. No damage had been done to our Naval establish-ments. Sixty-one Asiatics had been killed and 133 injured.The Secretary of State for the Colonies said that he hadreceived a report of an air raid that morning on Hong Kong andKowloon. Our casualties had been few. Kai Tak aerodrome had' ' been bombed, and some aircraft destroyed on the ground.Naval Pearl Harbour, Honolulu, had been attacked the previousOperations. evening by Japanese aircraft and submarines. The United states the Pacific authorities had been taken by surprise. The United States losses? included the battleship 0Mahoma, which had capsized, and a destroyer in dock which had been blown up. The battleshipTennessee, a destroyer and a minelayer had been set on fire. The' battleship Pennsylvania was probably undamaged.Shipping Losses. During the previous seven days 24,000 tons of merchantshipping had been sunk; losses from mines had been heavier than. usual.Military Apart from the forces contained in the Sollum-Bardia pocket,Operations. very few enemy remained between Tobruk and the EgyptianLibya. frontier and mopping-up operations were continuing. The bulk ofthe enemy forces were drawn up west of the line Tobruk-El Gobi.A number of New Zealand wounded, who had been takenprisoners, were now in our hands. We had recaptured the NewZealand guns which had been lost.Malaya. r The first Japanese attack on Kota Bahru had been repulsed,but subsequently enemy troops had succeeded in landing and were reported as infiltrating towards Kota Bahru aerodrome; They' were being engaged by our land and air forces.U.S.S.R. The position on the Russian front was satisfactory. The pincermovements directed against Moscow had not gained much ground.The position in the Ukraine was unchanged. In the Crimea theGermans were reported to be digging in at Kerch..Diversionary The1 Prime Minister said that it would now be necessary to callOperations. off certain diversiohary operations which had been planned, as wehad not now the necessary forces to spare. r ,.;The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.4 The Secretary of State for India said that the Governor-General :was anxious about the state of India's air defends.
